title: Please explain how a beneficiary loan account is calculated and paid, when the amount is less than assets of a trust
question: Four sibings are beneficiaries. Two owe monies to the trust,i.e. $20,000.00. The assets of the trust will be enough to clear the account balance. Should the beneficiary pay the trust cash because this abount will be added to the cash amount, then divided?
answers: This works out in the accounting on distribution. The debtor beneficiaries are treated as if their amounts are added to the trust, divided by 4 and then the debts are subtracted from the debtors' shares. For example, if the trust has $100,000 now and each debtor owes $20,000, the total available for distribution would be $140,000. Divided by 4 is $35,000 each. The debtor beneficiaries' share would be deducted by $20,000, so they would each get $15,000. The math works as 2 beneficiaries get net $35,000, and 2 get net $15,000, totalling $100,000, which is the cash on hand for distribution. The debtor beneficiaries get credit for their distributive share of 1/4 of the debt each.
